title: If life does indeed exist in the Venusian atmosphere, would that help us to calculate how common life might be in the Universe? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely. We would have two data points instead of one. It would be especially useful if we could get hold of a sample, and see whether it’s related to life on Earth. It has been proven that it is not impossible in principle for life to spread between two nearby planets. If it turns out it’s related to us, then further research will build on that: it is not only theoretically possible, but has actually happened. The odds for life on mars, for instance, will increase drastically, and we’ll probably go look for it. If it turns out it’s not related to us, then we can immediately deduce that life is likely to be extremely common. If it evolved on two separate occasions, and not only that but on the only two planets we’ve been able to investigate so far, that means it probably evolves everywhere it’s possible. We should expect life to be basically everywhere.

We will be able to say that we have observed organic life forms at two different locations in the solar system, but we will not have positively answered where that life originated. Was it on Venus or was it transplanted there from some other cosmic location of unknown origin? As always in science, each answer begets another question.
